B.2.4 
Healthcare-
Associated 
Ventriculitis 
and CSF 
shunt 
infections 
Bacterial: 
Staphylococci (MSSA, MRSA) 
Propionibacterium acnes  
Streptococcus pneumoniae 
Pseudomonas aeruginosa 
Haemophilus influenzae 
Extended spectrum β-lactamase-producing 
Gram-negative bacilli

Other Enterobacteriaceae 
Fungal:

B.3. Febrile Syndromes 
Annexure 
no. 
Title 
Etiology 
Reference 
B.3.1 
Acute 
undifferentia
ted fever 
Rickettsial agents: 
R. conorii 
R. rickettsii 
R. akari 
R. felis 
R. prowazekii  
R. typhi 
Orientia Tsutsugamushi 
Coxiella burnetii 
Rochalimaea quintana 
Harrison’s Principles of Internal 
Medicine Table 187-1, Pg 1432 
Leptospirosis: The Leptospira serovars 
predominantly present in India are 
L.andamana, L.pomona, 
L.grippotyphosa, L.hebdomadis, 
L.semoranga, L.javanica, L.autumnalis, 
L.canicola 
https://ncdc.mohfw.gov.in/wp-
content/uploads/2024/05/Nation
al-Guidelines-Diagnosis-Case-
Management-Prevention-control-
of-leptospirosis.pdf 
 
Malarial parasites:  
Plasmodium vivax, P. falciparum, P. 
ovale, P. malariae 
MALARIA DRUG POLICY 
Other etiological agents: 
Bacterial:  
Staphylococcus aureus 
Streptococcus pyogenes 
Pseudomonas aeruginosa 
other Gram-negative bacteria 
Fungal: Candida albicans  
Viral: Herpes simplex virus 
Rerucha CM, Ewing JT, 
Oppenlander KE, Cowan WC. 
Acute Hand Infections. Am Fam 
Physician. 2019 Feb 15;99(4):228-
236. PMID: 30763047. 
B.3.2 
Enteric fever 
Salmonella Typhi 
Salmonella Paratyphi A 
Salmonella Paratyphi B 
 
Harrison’s Principles of Internal 
Medicine 
B.3.3 
PUO 
Bacterial: 
Mycobacterium tuberculosis  
(extrapulmonary TB) 
Harrison’s Principles of Internal 
Medicine Chapter 20 table 20-2Pg 
146
